answers.answer: I don't think the stress test had a role in your symptoms, but I think they could be related to stress and anxiety even if you don't feel stressed or anxious.  We often carry the anxiety in our body without knowing it.  I sometimes have similar symptoms, but when I can really relax and forget them, they go away completely.  Good luck in finding answers.

anxiety is NOT your problem.  have you had an MRA?  That is in MRI with contrast that specifically studies veins/arteries.  some type of vasculitis could be the culprit.  if you have shown improvement with anti-inflammatories, then it seems that inflammation is probably causing your symptoms.  diagnosing the cause of the inflammation will be difficult as you know.i wouldn't be so quick to dismiss lymes, but i am not you and you know your symptoms best.  sometimes when lymes is not sufficiently treated, it can come back with a vengeance and cause new symptoms, even years later.

I would suspect lyme.  I had bullseye rashes in 1992 followed by a horrible infectious, neuro syndrome like MS.  MS was ruled out.  I took antibiotics for a few months and started improving.  It took about 5 years for me to feel almost normal.  It all hit again in 2005.  Again, numerous neuro tests...all negative.  I'm taking antibitics again and improving.  I have never had a positive lyme test but had 3 bullseye rashes.  Your symptoms sound very similar to mine.

question: I'm a 49 y/o male.Two months ago, the day after a heart stress test,  I experienced weakness from the knees down and numbness in the bottoms of my feet, mild headache, and a feeling of lightheadedness (off balance)--all this resulted in difficulty walking.About two weeks after the onset, I started to feel tingling on the left side of my body, from my face all the way down to my feet.I've had 4 MRIs (brain all the way down to lower back), lots of blood work (including checking for diabetes and thyroid), and leg emg. All results came back normal. I've seen a neurologist, primary care physician, orthopedic, and a neurology center at a renowned hospital. No one knows what is wrong with me.BTW, the stress test came back normal and no doc seems to think my problem is related to the stress test.After taking ibuprofen for the headache, I noticed that it relieved some of my neurological symptoms--then the PCP put me on 800mg/3 day and this relieved enough symptoms to allow me to function normally again. However, I believe that this is simply masking symptoms as I really don't feel like I'm improving more than 2 months later. In fact, I still have tingling in my hands and feet (more left than right, but both sides) , and occasional numbness on the bottom of both feet while on high doses of ibuprofen or naproxen. But these anti-inflammatories seems to relieve many symptoms.I'm on no other medications and am in good health otherwise (had a full physical just before falling ill) and in reasonable physical condition (I was exercising 3 times per weeks prior to falling ill and about 10 lbs overweight). I do have a long history of lyme disease, but I'm not showing any other lyme symptoms and after trying antibiotic treatments again, there has been no change in my neuro symptoms.Any ideas? What might these docs have missed? Might the stress test have a role in my problem?Thanks.
title: difficulty diagnosing neuroligical symtoms
